action_space.name: Therapeutic Relationship Establishment
action_space.description: The therapist demonstrates warmth, empathy, caring, and competence to foster a foundation for effective therapy and positive expectations.

goal.objective: Build trust and engage the patient in partnership

success_levels.ideal: Patient appears at ease, shares openly, and feels understood.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient is somewhat engaged but guarded.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is resistant, silent, or suspicious.

goal.reward_hint: Relationship warmth, trust, and patient openness are maximized.

states: First contact or early sessions where trust, rapport, or engagement is low or untested.
When the patient appears apprehensive, anxious, withdrawn, or skeptical.
Feedback indicates patient feels misunderstood.

micro_actions.name: Express Empathic Understanding
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge the patient's feelings and experiences, reflecting back their thoughts and emotions in your own words.
states: Patient appears distressed, misunderstood, or expresses negative affect; when patient reveals a difficult experience or emotion.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Patient Difficulties
micro_actions.description: Reframe the patient’s struggles as understandable and common in their context or diagnosis, reducing shame.
states: When patient expresses embarrassment, shame, or a sense of abnormality.

micro_actions.name: Seek Feedback on Session
micro_actions.description: Invite feedback about the session, asking if anything felt uncomfortable, unclear, or misunderstood.
states: At the end of any session, or after a potential misunderstanding or difficult discussion.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda Setting
micro_actions.description: Invite the patient to add items or select priorities for the session agenda, emphasizing teamwork.
states: Beginning of session or when patient has specific pressing concerns.

action_space.name: Initial Assessment and Cognitive Conceptualization
action_space.description: Gather information on the patient's problems, history, and patterns to build a ‘cognitive case conceptualization’ that informs treatment.

goal.objective: Develop an individualized, evolving understanding of the patient's difficulties in cognitive terms.

success_levels.ideal: Accurate conceptualization resonates with patient and guides effective intervention.
success_levels.acceptable: Conceptualization partially fits and evolves over sessions.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Conceptualization does not fit or guide interventions.

goal.reward_hint: Patient and therapist agree upon a personalized map of symptoms, thoughts, and beliefs.

states: First contact or evaluation session.
When changing or new symptoms appear.
After failed interventions or when stuck.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Problematic Situations
micro_actions.description: Ask about situations, contexts, or times where the patient feels most distressed or stuck.
states: Patient describes general distress or has difficulty specifying problems.

micro_actions.name: Ask for Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Query, ‘What was going through your mind?’ during episodes of distress.
states: Patient reports a negative mood or dysfunctional behavior.

micro_actions.name: Identify Core and Intermediate Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Clarify underlying beliefs or rules, using the downward arrow technique or direct questions.
states: Patterns emerge or interventions fail to shift mood or behavior.

micro_actions.name: Check Conceptualization with Patient
micro_actions.description: Summarize hypotheses about the patient’s patterns and seek explicit confirmation that they ‘ring true’.
states: After proposing a summary, pattern, or hypothesis.

action_space.name: Session Structuring and Agenda Management
action_space.description: Apply a repeatable session framework (mood check, agenda, homework review, problem/skill work, summary, feedback), using gentle interruption and reminders as needed.

goal.objective: Optimize session efficiency, focus, and predictability through clear structure.

success_levels.ideal: Session stays on track, key issues are prioritized, and patient feels guided yet involved.
success_levels.acceptable: Session somewhat structured; partial agenda completion.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Session is unfocused, rambling, or inefficient.

goal.reward_hint: Therapeutic aims are consistently achieved in each session.

states: Any session.
When discussion becomes tangential or time threatens to run out.
When working with new or less-structured patients.

micro_actions.name: Set Collaborative Agenda
micro_actions.description: Propose session flow and solicit the patient's additional priorities.
states: Beginning of session, after mood check.

micro_actions.name: Gently Interrupt and Refocus
micro_actions.description: Tactfully bring the focus back to a set agenda item or summarize when conversation drifts.
states: Patient provides excessive detail or digresses from the agenda.

micro_actions.name: Summarize Session Segments
micro_actions.description: After each topic or agenda item, summarize key points for clarity.
states: Transitioning between topics, after major discussions.

micro_actions.name: Review Homework at Start
micro_actions.description: Check-in on progress with previous assignments and collaboratively address obstacles.
states: Early part of session, prior to new problem work.

action_space.name: Guided Discovery and Cognitive Restructuring
action_space.description: Through Socratic questioning and behavioral experiments, help the patient evaluate the evidence, consider alternative viewpoints, and form more adaptive beliefs.

goal.objective: Teach the patient to identify, examine, and respond to dysfunctional thoughts and beliefs.

success_levels.ideal: Patient learns to question and modify thinking, leading to improved mood and behavior outside sessions.
success_levels.acceptable: Therapist guides restructuring, but patient needs prompts for self-use.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient unable or unwilling to identify/modify thoughts.

goal.reward_hint: Cognitive shifts are observed and practiced.

states: During emotional distress or recurrence of problematic thoughts.
After identification of unhelpful/automatic thoughts.
When facing prospective or past negative situations.

micro_actions.name: Use Socratic Questions
micro_actions.description: Ask evidence-based questions: 'What is the evidence for/against?', 'Are there alternative ways of viewing this?', etc.
states: Patient endorses a negative thought or prediction.

micro_actions.name: Develop Behavioral Experiments
micro_actions.description: Work with patient to test predictions or beliefs through planned, real-world actions.
states: Predictions are testable or beliefs are rigid.

micro_actions.name: Distinguish Thought from Emotion
micro_actions.description: Clarify if a patient's report is a thought, feeling, or action, and label appropriately.
states: Patient reports confusion between emotions and thoughts.

micro_actions.name: Record Adaptive Responses
micro_actions.description: Summarize new perspectives in writing for use between sessions.
states: After a cognitive restructuring segment.

action_space.name: Behavioral Activation and Skills Training
action_space.description: Guide the patient in identifying, scheduling, and tracking activities that promote mastery and/or pleasure, and teach necessary skills to reduce distress.

goal.objective: Increase healthy, adaptive behaviors and reduce avoidance/inactivity.

success_levels.ideal: Patient increases activity, experiences mastery and pleasure, and notes improvement in mood.
success_levels.acceptable: Partial increase in activity or skills use.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains avoidant, passive, or behavior does not change.

goal.reward_hint: Patient's functioning and activity level improve.

states: Patient presents with inactivity, avoidance, or passivity.
When problem solving indicates skills/behavioral deficits.
When mood is low and engagement with tasks is minimal.

micro_actions.name: Activity Scheduling
micro_actions.description: Collaborate to identify specific, realistic, and rewarding activities for the week ahead.
states: Patient is withdrawing from activities, feeling anhedonic, or has poor daily structure.

micro_actions.name: Anticipate and Address Behavioral Obstacles
micro_actions.description: Elicit and respond to thoughts or feelings likely to interfere with doing activities.
states: During planning stages of activity assignment; patient voices doubts.

micro_actions.name: Assign Graded Tasks
micro_actions.description: Help break large, overwhelming tasks into smaller, more achievable steps.
states: When a patient feels overwhelmed or stalls on large goals.

micro_actions.name: Review Mastery/Pleasure Ratings
micro_actions.description: Have patient rate activities for sense of accomplishment and enjoyment to reinforce adaptive behavior.
states: After activities are performed; at homework review.

micro_actions.name: Train in Specific Skills
micro_actions.description: Directly teach problem-solving, assertiveness, relaxation, or other needed behavioral skills.
states: Patient displays skills deficits or repeatedly encounters similar problems.

action_space.name: Homework Assignment and Review
action_space.description: Prescribe individually-tailored, collaboratively-set tasks for the patient to practice new thinking, behavior, or skills between sessions and troubleshoot barriers.

goal.objective: Reinforce skill use and insight development between sessions, solidifying therapy gains.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes and self-monitors homework, enabling in-session and independent change.
success_levels.acceptable: Partial or inconsistent homework completed; learning still occurs.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Homework not attempted or actively avoided, leading to therapy stagnation.

states: End of each session; when reviewing progress.
Patient expresses difficulty applying skills between sessions.
Ongoing throughout therapy.

micro_actions.name: Assign Tailored Homework
micro_actions.description: Suggest specific, achievable assignments based on session content and patient capacity; ensure buy-in.
states: End of session, after new skill or insight established.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Troubleshooting
micro_actions.description: Anticipate obstacles and brainstorm solutions to likely homework barriers before end of session.
states: As homework is assigned and potential barriers identified.

micro_actions.name: Reinforce Rationale for Homework
micro_actions.description: Clearly link the assignment to symptom improvement and personal therapy goals.
states: Whenever a new or disliked homework is proposed.

micro_actions.name: Homework Completion Check-In
micro_actions.description: At the start of the following session, inquire about homework follow-through and adjust if incomplete.
states: First few minutes of session.

action_space.name: Relapse Prevention and Termination Preparation
action_space.description: Actively teach self-therapy structures, help recognize warning signs of relapse, and review mastery of CBT tools as therapy nears conclusion.

goal.objective: Equip the patient to be their own therapist and maintain progress post-therapy.

success_levels.ideal: Patient independently uses CBT skills and copes with setbacks without therapist input.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient occasionally needs reminders or booster sessions.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient relapses without skills application; dependent on therapist.

goal.reward_hint: Stable gains and low relapse risk post-treatment.

states: Mid-late therapy once symptoms improve.
As therapy frequency tapers or termination planned.

micro_actions.name: Review Self-Therapy Tools
micro_actions.description: Summarize and rehearse main techniques with the patient for future use.
states: Final phase of therapy or prior to breaks/termination.

micro_actions.name: Plan for Setbacks
micro_actions.description: Anticipate potential difficulties and develop coping strategies and support plans collaboratively.
states: Last several sessions; when patient expresses anxiety about managing alone.

micro_actions.name: Booster Session Scheduling
micro_actions.description: Arrange periodic follow-ups for monitoring and support after formal termination.
states: At or near last session; ongoing maintenance.

conversation_states.Description: Degree to which the patient trusts and engages with the therapist; essential for collaborative empiricism and positive outcomes.
Level of active, collaborative involvement by the patient in the therapy process—agenda, feedback, and homework.
Current level of the patient’s targeted distress (depression, anxiety, etc.) and its trajectory over time.
Patient’s ability to notice and articulate automatic thoughts at or soon after moments of emotional shift.
Patient’s facility with identifying, evaluating, and adaptively responding to dysfunctional thinking.
Degree of activity, mastery-related, and pleasurable behaviors performed between sessions.
Level of strength/flexibility of target dysfunctional beliefs.
Ratio of homework assignments completed per session.
Patient’s grasp of maintenance strategies and self-therapy skills for enduring change.

nodes.description: Root node representing the individual receiving therapy.
Comprehensive clinical diagnosis for current and past mental health issues.
Chief complaints and target difficulties identified in therapy.
Deep, global beliefs about self, others, and the world.
Conditional rules, attitudes, and assumptions derived from core beliefs.
Observed patterns or responses, including safety, avoidant, or activation behaviors.
Emotion types, intensity, and variations observed and reported.
Adaptive or maladaptive behavioral responses to symptoms or beliefs.
Key early experiences and learning shaping beliefs/behavior.
Abilities, values, positive qualities, and social supports.
Collaboratively defined positive outcomes sought in therapy.
Concise recaps of session content, learning, and homework.
Longitudinal record of assignments and their completion.
Strategies and supports for maintenance post-therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Arguing or Persuading Instead of Guided Discovery
cautions.description: Directly challenging or debating patient's thoughts/beliefs rather than collaboratively exploring through Socratic questioning.
cautions.risk: May cause defensiveness, reduce engagement, and undermine collaborative empiricism.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring Feedback or Negative Affect Shifts
cautions.description: Failing to notice, elicit, or address patient feedback, discomfort, or negative nonverbal cues during sessions.
cautions.risk: Can damage the therapeutic alliance, lead to dropout or misunderstanding.

cautions.negative_action: Moving Too Quickly to Core Beliefs
cautions.description: Forcing attention to deep core beliefs before the patient is ready or before necessary skills and trust are built.
cautions.risk: Can destabilize the patient, foster resistance, or damage alliance.

cautions.description: Rigidly adhering to structure at the expense of flexibility or patient needs.
cautions.risk: May reduce engagement, miss emerging clinical issues or alienate some patients.

cautions.description: Failing to review or assign homework collaboratively and consistently.
cautions.risk: Undermines learning, limits generalization of skills, and reduces therapy efficacy.

cautions.negative_action: Assuming Patient is Resistant or Difficult Without Conceptualization
cautions.description: Blaming the patient for lack of progress or engagement instead of reviewing and revising conceptualization and approach.
cautions.risk: Therapist may miss solvable factors and foster negative cycles.

cautions.description: Spending disproportionate time on developmental history when here-and-now interventions or problem-solving are more pressing.
cautions.risk: Misses opportunities for symptom relief and skill learning, may lower motivation.

cautions.negative_action: Skimping on Relapse Prevention Near Termination
cautions.description: Ending therapy without a clear, practiced plan for self-maintenance and setback navigation.
cautions.risk: Increases risk of post-therapy relapse and reduces durable gains.
